# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Sure, here is how you can solve this problem in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(input_str::String; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(input_str, " ")
    str_lengths = [length(word) for word in words]
    line_words = []
    current_line_len = 0
    
    for (i, word) in enumerate(words)
        if current_line_len + str_lengths[i] > text_width
            push!(line_words, join(line_words))
            empty!(line_words)
            current_line_len = 0
        end
        push!(line_words, word)
        current_line_len += str_lengths[i] + 1 # Adding one for the space that follows each word.
    end
    return join(vcat(line_words), "\n")
end
```

For your given example, you would call `wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")` and it should return:

```julia
"This function\nwill wrap\nwords into\nlines"
```

It's important to note that this function is case-sensitive. It treats "function" and "Function" as two different words, for example. If you want the function to be case-insensitive, you can convert all words to lowercase or uppercase before processing them.
